speaker: Neil
text: Welcome to 6 Minute English, the programme where we explore an interesting topic and bring you six bits of useful vocabulary. I'm Neil.

speaker: first impressions
text: And I'm Rob. Today we're talking about first impressions – and how they're often wrong.

speaker: first impression
text: So let's start with the term first impression – it's the idea or opinion you have about someone after meeting them for only a short time.

speaker: Rob
text: It's very natural to make a quick judgement about someone based on their appearance or facial expression.

speaker: Neil
text: We're going to be hearing about the research of Professor Alexander Todorov from Princeton University in the US. First, a question: how long does he say it takes to form an impression about someone's face? Is it...

speaker: Neil
text: a) under one second

speaker: Neil
text: b) one second

speaker: Neil
text: c) six seconds

speaker: Rob
text: I'll go for b) one second.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, we'll find out if you're right or not at the end of the programme.

speaker: trustworthyextroverted
text: So – Alexander Todorov has been researching our impressions. His tests asked people to decide whether they thought faces were dominant, competent, trustworthy or extroverted.

speaker: Neil
text: Let's just look at those words for a second. Dominant means being strongest or most important. Competent means being able to do things.

speaker: trustworthy
text: While if you're trustworthy it means people trust you – you are worth their trust. And being extroverted means you are energetic and enjoy spending time with others.

speaker: trustworthy
text: So what did he find out? Faces that look happy and feminine – like a woman - were rated as more trustworthy.

speaker: Rob
text: While faces that were more masculine – like a man – were seen as more dominant.

speaker: extroverted
text: Wider faces with big eyes were seen as more extroverted.

speaker: Rob
text: Now the important thing that Todorov says is that these judgements aren't accurate. Someone who looks competent isn't necessarily competent!

speaker: Neil
text: So, what does this mean in practice? Here's Professor Todorov:

speaker: Trustworthinessperceivedattribute
text: Trustworthiness, dominance and attractiveness are the three big things that we form impressions of people. But interestingly we have done some work predicting the electoral success of politicians, and the judgement that is most predictive of who is going to win the election is perceived competence. And this is not random at all, because if you ask voters what is the most important attribute of a politician, competence is the one on the top.

speaker: attribute
text: OK, so this is actually quite significant. People say that the most important attribute – or quality – for a politician is competence – the ability to do things.

speaker: Rob
text: That sounds fair enough. But because we make judgements based on appearance – this can actually affect how people vote.

speaker: perceive
text: If voters believe – or perceive someone to be competent – they're more likely to vote for him or her.

speaker: Rob
text: He says this applies especially to people who are less educated about politics – they are more likely to be influenced by appearance.

speaker: go with their gut
text: He says this applies to around 25% of voters – so the number of people who go with their gut is large enough to influence the outcomes of elections!

speaker: To go withyour gut
text: Wow. To go with your gut. That means to make a decision which isn't based on rational thought – it's based on instinct, on a feeling, on your gut.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes – your gut is your stomach and the organs in your belly. So, can we tell nothing from a person's face?

speaker: Rob
text: Todorov says faces carry useful information about things like a person's mental state, and whether they're tired or sick. But they don't tell you about a person's character.

speaker: Neil
text: Indeed. It's not only elections where this counts, we also judge during job interviews and meetings.

speaker: Rob
text: So what can we do to minimise the chances of being affected – should we just close our eyes when we meet people?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, it's not such a bad idea! There's the example of the Boston Symphony Orchestra – back in the 1950s it was entirely made up of male musicians. They then introduced 'blind auditions' in other words they listened to new musicians without looking at them.

speaker: Rob
text: And what happened – I guess many more women were selected?

speaker: Neil
text: Exactly – around 50%. Of course, gender and race are also huge factors in how we perceive faces. Todorov says we tend to react most positively to faces that look like our own.

speaker: Rob
text: Right, well – I guess we just need to take a deep breath and try not to judge too much.

speaker: Neil
text: Easier said than done, I'm afraid. Especially when we judge so quickly! But do we do it in under a second, one second or six seconds?

speaker: Rob
text: I said one second.

speaker: Neil
text: According to Todorov it takes under one second.

speaker: Rob
text: I think it's safe to say it's very fast. So shall we quickly go through today's vocabulary?

speaker: first impressionfirst impression
text: Ok – first up: first impression – the first judgement you make about something. What was your first impression of me, Rob?

speaker: trustworthyextroverted.
text: Well I thought you were very trustworthy and extroverted.

speaker: trustworthy
text: Well isn't that convenient, (and accurate?!), because those were exactly the two adjectives I wanted to look at next. Being trustworthy is important in life – it means people trust you…

speaker: extrovertedextroverts
text: And being extroverted is more of a character type – extroverts like to be with people, and are often seen as confident – whereas the opposite – introverts, usually need to spend time on their own, and aren't as loud.

speaker: attributes attribute
text: Both of these are interesting attributes – or qualities. You could say that mathematical ability is an essential attribute for an engineer.

speaker: perception
text: And competence is the number one attribute for a politician. Although people don't always vote depending on actual competence, they base it on their perception.

speaker: perceivePerceived
text: What they see, or perceive, as competence. 'Perceived competence' might be different from actual competence!

speaker: go with our guts
text: Yes, in many situations we tend to go with our guts. We make decisions based on deep feelings. Do you do that, Neil?

speaker: went with my gut
text: Yes, some things you can think about too much. When I left my last job, I really just went with my gut – it felt like the right thing to do.

speaker: Rob
text: Of course – because it meant coming to work here with me!

speaker: Neil
text: Naturally. So – that's it for our chat about first impressions – for more do visit our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube pages, and of course our website!

speaker: Rob
text: Bye for now.

speaker: Both
text: Bye!
